title: Rasam (dish)
text:
Rasam () is a clear and spicy <a href="South%20Indian">South Indian</a> <a href="soup">soup</a>. It is eaten with rice or consumed as a soup. In a traditional South Indian meal, it can be part of a course that includes <a href="sambar%20%28dish%29">sambar</a> rice and <a href="curd%20rice">curd rice</a>. Rasam has a distinct taste in comparison to <a href="Sambar%20%28dish%29">sambar</a> due to its own seasoning ingredients and is fluid in consistency. Chilled prepared versions are marketed commercially as well as rasam paste in bottles.
Origin.
' in <a href="Malayalam">Malayalam</a> and <a href="Tamil%20language">Tamil</a>, ' in <a href="Kannada%20language">Kannada</a> (<a href="Kannada%20script">Kannada script</a>: ), or "" in Telugu means "essence" and, by extension, "juice" or "soup". In <a href="South%20Indian">South Indian</a> households "rasam" commonly refers to a soup prepared with sweet-sour stock made from either <a href="kokum">kokum</a> or <a href="tamarind">tamarind</a>, along with <a href="tomato">tomato</a> and <a href="dal">lentil</a>, added spices and garnish.
The Malayalam word ("") and the corresponding word in Tamil (, transliterated: ) were borrowed from Sanskrit (transliterated: ); literally, sap, juice, or essence. The Sanskrit word also yielded the English word <a href="Rasa%20%28aesthetics%29">rasa</a>, in the aesthetic sense.
Ingredients.
Rasam is prepared mainly with <a href="kokum">kokum</a>, <a href="onion">onion</a>, <a href="malabar%20tamarind">malabar tamarind</a> "(kudam puli)", <a href="tamarind">tamarind</a>, <a href="Ambula%20%28food%29">ambula</a>, or <a href="amchur">amchur</a> (dried green mango) stock depending on the region. Along with <a href="tomato">tomato</a> stock, <a href="dal">dal or lentil</a> (for rasam, the typical dal used is split yellow pigeon peas or Toor dal) are optional but are used in several rasam recipes. <a href="Jaggery">Jaggery</a>, cumin, <a href="black%20pepper">black pepper</a>, <a href="turmeric">turmeric</a>, mustard seeds, <a href="lemon">lemon</a>, chilli powder, <a href="Murraya%20koenigii">curry leaves</a>, <a href="garlic">garlic</a> and <a href="coriander">coriander</a> may be used as flavoring ingredients and garnish in <a href="South%20India">South India</a>.
